title: Was there any human progress in the middle ages? - Quora

response.answer_text: Certainly there was.   In Europe, people began using a Horse collar, originally developed in China.  This in combination with a Carruca, or heavy plow, brought much more land under cultivation and greatly increased the food supply. In the Muslim world, alchemists applied many of the techniques first worked out by the Greeks (Alchemy and chemistry in medieval Islam) and developed specialized equipment for experiments that would eventually lead to modern chemistry. In India, mathematicians developed the concept of zero as a number, which let a positional number system (first tried a few centuries before in Babylon) function as a logically consistent scheme. In Persia, horizontal windmills were first used to grind grain and draw water.  This invention quickly spread through Asia and Europe. In China, gunpowder was first formulated and used to fire weapons.  This invention was soon spread to Europe and the Middle East when it was taken up by the Mongols.

One of the most notable occurrences during the Middle ages was the birth of Paris.  From a tiny town to a bustling metropolis it became the cultural, academic and artistic centre of Europe.  One of the world's first and most prominent Universities originated in Paris and others such as Oxford sprung up in Britain, academia became more available.
